entry.title: Combined summary - Introducing BitcoinKit.framework
entry.summary: The discussion begins with a suggestion to use C++ for more flexibility on other platforms and Android compatibility through NDK, but the other person points out that bitcoinj already runs SPV wallets on Android without requiring the NDK. The conversation then shifts to j2c, a tool for transpiling Java code into C++. They caution that j2c was written for fun and isn't documented well, but they are currently fixing bugs and improving it.In July 2013, Wendell expressed interest in an open dissection of adding Simplified Payment Verification (SPV) support to bitcoind. If someone completes such a patch, Wendell said he is willing to fund or co-fund the endeavor. Mike Hearn offered to send Satoshi's old patch for SPV mode implementation, indicating the basic cut lines. Satoshi suggested in 2010 that client-only nodes should receive full blocks so they can scan for their own transactions instead of indexing them. The code for this mode is mostly implemented and available on Github, but it's not fully finished for end-users.Recently, Bitcoin developer Mike Hearn approved of the idea of headers-first sync, which involves synchronizing only the headers of a blockchain before requesting blocks along the best chain. This approach is seen as a useful step towards simplified payment verification (SPV) mode. The launch of BitcoinKit.framework has been announced, which allows developers to create Bitcoin wallet applications for Mac OS X using bitcoind and a small API. Support for other Bitcoin implementations is soon to follow. The best fix for long synchronization times for new users is SPV mode, but so far, the only SPV mode implementation is bitcoinj.A Java-based implementation of the Bitcoin protocol, called Bitcoinj, is planning to use simplified payment verification (SPV) mode, which is headers-first sync without the full block sync step, replacing it with bloom/birthday-based fetching of blocks interesting to associated wallets. Pieter Wuille is working on headers-first sync, which he believes is generally very useful and fixes many edge-cases block synchronization that the blockchain currently experiences. Bitcoinj aims to store only relevant outputs in the wallet to save memory, as some users have wallets that don't fit in RAM. SPV mode requires a disabled mempool and other small changes.The developer is experimenting with trans-piling bitcoinj to C++ to make it usable from Objective-C++. There are different options for implementing a native client for Bitcoin, including embedding the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) or transpiling bitcoinj to C++. Embedding the JVM requires less work and can achieve good results quickly. The primary problem with the Oracle JVM is the lack of retina support for Swing, but this doesn't matter if the app uses a Cocoa UI. Retina support for JavaFX2, the current-gen GUI toolkit, is available in Java 8. Transpiling bitcoinj to C++ requires a significant amount of work but could result in a stable, portable, and extendable piece of code. Overall, both options have their pros and cons.The conversation also includes a discussion of j2c, which is a tool for transpiling Java code into C++. The speaker suggests looking into the quality of j2c's output and provides an example link. They caution that j2c was written for fun and isn't documented well, but they are currently fixing bugs and improving it. The resulting code requires Boehm GC and may have unused generated code, which needs to be eliminated during linking to avoid huge binaries.Headers-first sync is seen as a useful step towards simplified payment verification (SPV) mode, where full block syncing is replaced with a bloom-based fetching of interesting blocks for associated wallets. Although there will be more changes required for SPV mode, disabling the mempool and making small modifications, the separate headers-sync phase will be the bulk of the work. BitcoinKit.framework has been launched, which enables developers to create Bitcoin wallet applications for Mac OS X, with Hive being the first application to use BitcoinKit as its backbone.
